sentence: Even the most experienced investors were once considered rookies, having to endure the learning curves, the ups and downs that come with learning about investing in stocks.
But new investors don't have to go it alone.

Check out The Motley Fool's 13 Steps to Investing Foolishly and read on for advice from three Fool contributors who want to help you invest better and have brought you a look at Disney, Apple, and Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway.
Rick Munarriz : The first stock I ever owned was Disney , and I'm probably not the only one that got my first taste of investing with the House of Mouse.
Disney is a popular stock for first timers, particularly gifted by parents and grandparents to young investors given the family-friendly media giant's iconic characters.

Between the theme parks, Disney Channel, and the consumer products it's easy to explain to children how every turnstile click at Disneyland or every Winnie the Pooh plush bear sold trickles down to Disney's coffers.
However, Disney isn't merely a Mickey Mouse company anymore.
It has spent billions to acquire Capital Cities/ABC, Pixar, Marvel, and more recently Lucasfilm to create a gargantuan media empire that includes ESPN, Toy Story , The Avengers , and Star Wars .
The end result is that there are more moving parts to the Disney story.
You have to watch ad rates at ABC, the high costs of computer-rendered animation at Pixar, and the feast-or-famine nature of big-budget superhero and sci-fi flicks in assessing Disney's performance.
Deep down inside, you probably don't mind.
Hitting up your local multiplex to catch Guardians of the Galaxy recently or making it down to Florida next summer for a ride on Space Mountain isn't too shabby when it comes to field research.
Along the way, you have a company that has expanded its core offerings.
There are now Disney theme parks all over the world, with Shanghai Disneyland slated to open next year.
There are now four Disney cruise ships.
Its resorts have expanded with lavish hotels adjacent to its theme parks as well as stand-alone properties that are part of Disney's high-end timeshare program.
The pieces fit in this collection of magnetic entertainment properties that topped $45 billion in revenue last year, and should continue to grow at a slow yet steady pace in the future.
: I think Berkshire Hathaway is a great beginner's stock, and not just because, as a shareholder, you get to partner with one of the best investors of all time in CEO Warren Buffett.
Berkshire is also a fantastically diverse business, through which you can get exposure to some of the strongest companies around.

These include massive blue chips like American Express and Procter & Gamble , but also dozens of smaller brands -- running the gamut from insurance giant GEICO to confectioner See's Candy -- that you just couldn't invest in on your own.
Besides diversification, Berkshire carries two more advantages that I think make it perfect for investing novices.
For one, the business tends to perform particularly well during economic downturns.
In 2008, for example, when the stock market plunged by 37%, Berkshire's book value shrunk by less than 10% and the stock outperformed the S&P 500 to boot.
One of the biggest risks you face as an investor is panic selling during a downturn, and Berkshire's sturdiness makes that worst-case scenario less likely.
Second, it's a safe bet that you'll learn a lot about business and investing as a Berkshire shareholder.
Buffett's yearly letters are packed with financial wisdom in addition to some of the most honest, direct communication you'll see from a management team.

Here's just one example from this year's letter:

With Berkshire, investors know exactly what they're getting, which is a diverse business with a world-class management team.
Brian Nichols : One of the wisest pieces of early advice I ever received was to invest in companies that I understood.
When you're a rookie, don't try and get fancy.
Invest in companies that make products or provide services that you use in your everyday life.
Apple is a company the average consumer understands, a company with products used by a lot of people.
In its third quarter, it sold over 39 million iPhones, 12.3 million iPads, and 5.5 million Macs.
According to statistics site netmarketshare.com, Apple's operating system, iOS, holds a 43.8% market share of the mobile plus tablet industry worldwide.
In other words, Apple is a highly recognizable company, so you don't have to be a genius to understand what makes the company successful.
Apple's stock also has a number of factors that are sure to make it a top investment choice for anxious and uncertain new investors.
First, it trades at just 12.4 times next year's expected earnings versus a forward P/E ratio of 16 on the S&P 500.
This indicates that Apple's stock is actually undervalued and cheaper relative to the broader market, giving its stock a good shot to outperform the performance of the S&P 500 long term.
Second, Apple's stock has a 1.8% annual dividend yield .
This means that Apple pays investors to own its stock, essentially providing 1.8% of downside protection.
In addition, Apple buys back more stock than any other company , spending $17 billion during the last quarter buying its own stock .
This serves as even more downside protection, adding additional buying pressure to the stock.
These combined factors make Apple the perfect stock for beginners.

Top dividend stocks for the next decade

The smartest investors know that dividend stocks simply crush their non-dividend paying counterparts over the long term.
That's beyond dispute.
They also know that a well-constructed dividend portfolio creates wealth steadily, while still allowing you to sleep like a baby.
Knowing how valuable such a portfolio might be, our top analysts put together a report on a group of high-yielding stocks that should be in any income investor's portfolio.
To see our free report on these stocks, just click here .
